I can also live with the proposed change, but I think for now being more explicit in those tables might be better.

pulls.title: symmetric algorithm preferences: clarify what happens in the absence …
pulls.author: TJ-91
pulls.body:
…of the subpackets

Closes #106 

Not sure if the last sentence is really required, but the Crypto Refresh leaves a lot of room for implementations to determine v2 SEIPD support so it can't hurt.

comments.author: TJ-91
comments.body:
@wussler @dkg Thanks for the fixes and suggestions.

The reason I wrote the text is given in #106:
> The crypto-refresh does not clearly state that the implicit lists of preferred algorithms are in force even when the respective subpacket is missing. We should clarify this at least in the PQC specification.

In `5.2.3.15. Preferred AEAD Ciphersuites` strictly speaking, it is not described what happens in the absence of the subpacket. The same is true for the non-AEAD stuff (see `12.2. Symmetric Algorithm Preferences`).

I do think it's not a problem in the Crypto Refresh since it's clear enough what algorithm to choose in such a case since there is only one choice left, the MTI algorithm. Now we extend this mechanism and set more implicit default options to the lists of the subpackets. Now there is ambiguity in the case of a missing subpacket.

I am also not very happy with the additional text but with the reasoning I gave, do you still think we can drop this clarification completely?

comments.author: wussler
comments.body: I am also happy with @dkg's proposed text, and I think it's now clear what to do in the case of missing subpackets. I also think here would be the right place to add a "forbid SED tag 9" for issue #91

comments.author: dkg
comments.body:
@TJ-91 i see what you're saying about the specifics of what is missing, but (a) the text you're proposing is a _lot_ of words to say "for these purposes, treat a missing subpacket the same as an empty subpacket", and (b) i don't really know what the alternative interpretation would be likely to be.  are you suggesting that an implementer might really think "if they have an empty AEAD ciphersuites subpacket, then i know i can use AES256-OCB, but if they have a missing AEAD ciphersuites subpacket, then i know i have to fall back to AES128-OCB"?  That would be very weird.

Maybe this would be best illustrated in a test vector, with a minimal certificate with a PQ/T encryption key, and a features packet that supports v2 SEIPD, and no AEAD Ciphersuites subpacket.  then the test vector could include an encrypted message that uses AES256-OCB .

comments.author: TJ-91
comments.body:
> are you suggesting that an implementer might really think "if they have an empty AEAD ciphersuites subpacket, then i know i can use AES256-OCB, but if they have a missing AEAD ciphersuites subpacket, then i know i have to fall back to AES128-OCB"? That would be very weird.

That's true, there is not much potential for harm here.

> Maybe this would be best illustrated in a test vector

I don't think the test vector really conveys the message (many would probably not notice the detail or if they do, be confused by it).

```suggestion
Support for the v2 SEIPD feature MUST NOT be assumed on the basis of implicitly added AEAD algorithm pairs alone.
```

I think the rest of the text is already clear enough about the SEIPDv1 and AEAD. The remaining sounded to me just like a repetition that made the overall concept less clear.

reviews.author: dkg
reviews.body:
I think this text can be further simplified while still getting across the main point.

I don't think implementers need reminding that "missing subpacket is the same as empty subpacket" -- in any case, if they do this might not be the right place to put it.

We're talking here about adding additional inference about supported encryption algorithms.  rather than stating what the implementation should *not* do (infer v2 SEIPD support on the basis of the PQ(/T) key alone), we should be explicit about what they *should* do: 

- look at the Features subpacket (today), or
- infer support for v2 SEIPD based on some survey of widely available implementations that support PQC (in the future, when such a survey is available).

comments.body: s/describhed/described/

this final line is passive voice: who is doing the assuming or not assuming?

How about being clearer, like: 

> When encrypting to a OpenPGP certificate that contains a PQ(/T) key, an implementation MUST NOT infer that the certificate's owner supports v2 SEIPD solely on the basis of the implicitly added AEAD algorithm pairs.

i tend to agree with @wussler here that we probably don't need to say "lack of subpacket is the same as empty subpacket".  We also don't want to imply that any implementation should consider the presence of either encryption-support subpacket as the same as the appropriate bit in the Features subpacket.

The bottom line seems to be that there is consenus to only add the sentence that @dkg propsed above. In that case I ask @TJ-91 to update the PR accordingly. I am ready to close issue #106, which was the reason for the initially proposed changes in this PR, that was raised by me as irrelevant.

pulls.author: TJ-91

reviews.author: wussler
reviews.body: Just minor formatting comments

pulls.title: Switch KDF to  SHA3-256
pulls.author: wussler
pulls.body: Adapt the KDF proposal to the discussion held at IETF 119

comments.author: wussler
comments.body: @TJ-91 should be fixed

comments.author: wussler
comments.body:
Ufff, I forgot in how many places we referenced this...

> I think in most of the places it would be better to write "SHA3-256" instead of just "SHA-3", what do you think?

Makes sense, since we use explicitly only this algo

I also rewrote the security consideration, cutting out the proof for the omission of the PKs and adapting the references

reviews.author: TJ-91
reviews.body:
I can decrypt the updated test vectors so it looks good from that side.
There are still some things that need to be fixed in the document:

* There are still multiple occurances of `KMAC`
* `multiKeyCombine`:
  * `//   customizationString - the UTF-8 encoding of the string "KDF"` should be removed
  * Not sure if `domSeparation` really needs to be a constant in the `multiKeyCombine` any longer
  * the lines describing the `ecdhKeyShare` and `ecdhCipherText` have incorrect whitespaces

reviews.author: TJ-91
reviews.body:
I think in most of the places it would be better to write "SHA3-256" instead of just "SHA-3", what do you think?

Another thing I just noticed is in Section 9.3. 
> Furthermore, we do not require the recipients public key into the key combiner as the public key material is already included in the component key derivation functions. Given two KEMs which we assume to be multi-user secure, we combine their outputs using a KEM-combiner:

I suppose that's not how we do it anymore.

Also the first two paragraphs that describe the `fixedInfo` and the domain separation are not 100% accurate any longer since we mix the two now in the `fixedInfo`. The reference to Section 4.2.2 for `domSeparation` is also wrong now.

Probably we can just slightly rewrite the first three paragraphs and remove the rest

comments.body: It might make sense to prefix the algID with a length field. That makes the construction forward compatible even when multi byte algorithm IDs should be introduced.

However, I think we are running into problem when doing it naively this way. Since the fixedInfo comes at the end, the whole string is currently only unabigously parsable from its rear end. But then we would need right-encoding of the algorithm ID field, i.e. `fixedInfo = algID || len(algID) || domSeparation`.

I also think we should encode it at the end, if we do so.

On the other hand, in this (unlinkely) case, I think we could also alter the domain separation? We'll need a new key/PKESK/... version for that

I do not think that the string needs to be parsed, so it shouldn't matter where we place it from that perspective.

I assume you are worried about ambiguities / collisions where the boundary between the alg ID byte(s) and the KEM bytes clash? When viewing both the length, and the KEM input as "arbitrary length and arbitrary content" strings, wouldn't we have the same problem even when encoding the length of the algorithm ID? Since we have multiple variable-length fields following each other without a clear boundary. Thus, we need to prefix the length of the other variable input (the KEM data), too.

Also, I would change it to simply `0x01` instead of `len(algID)`, since multi-byte IDs are only a remote possibility now.
Further, I agree with Aron, that we will always have the freedom to adjust the KEM inputs for newly introduced algorithms. The `domSeparation` could then be used to unambigously define the "version" of the KDF.

> When viewing both the length, and the KEM input as "arbitrary length and arbitrary content" strings, wouldn't we have the same problem even when encoding the length of the algorithm ID? Since we have multiple variable-length fields following each other without a clear boundary. Thus, we need to prefix the length of the other variable input (the KEM data), too.

What I propose aims exactly at solving this problem. When the string is anambiguously parsable from the rear, collisions cannot happen: after the algorithm ID has been parsed from the rear, the lengths of the other fields are known.

Changing the domain separation string might again lead to possible collisions. Thus the new  domain separation string would need to be of the same length as the current one. Maybe we should include a two digit (i.e. two byte) version number in the `domSeparation` string and set it to "00" for now.

> after the algorithm ID has been parsed from the rear, the lengths of the other fields are known.

You are right, that does fix it. We can still consider prefixing all variable-length fields but that's just a matter of preference (but it might become required if we introduce more variable-length fields).

> Maybe we should include a two digit (i.e. two byte) version number in the `domSeparation` string and set it to "00" for now.

I think it's a good idea. Alternatively, we can use one byte, e.g., `fixedInfo = algID || len(algID) || KDFVersion || domSeparation`. However, I don't think there are any benefits of one over the other.
Making the domain separation `OpenPGPCompositeKDFv1`

pulls.title: Rewrite parallel encryption guidance
pulls.author: wussler
pulls.body:
This PR addresses #2 and #67, removing the normative section about recipients, and making it an example for applications supporting it.
A review of all the terms "recipient" and "sender" was done, to remove the implicit reference to email

reviews.author: falko-strenzke
reviews.body:
I think the PR achieves what was agreed on in the interim. I am not sure that the new term "communication party" is avoiding the notion of a message transmission completely, but it clearly seems to be an improvement over "recipient". I also don't find any better term.

Once my proposed correction was decided on, I will approve this PR.

comments.body:
This is not pertaining to the changes, but to the text as was before: Actually, whether the encryption has to be considered "multi algorithm" or not depends on whether the set of keys used belong to different algorithms. So  probably we should rather write: 
```suggestion
Accordingly, when a message is encrypted using multiple PKESK packages for different encryption keys, a non-composite, potentially multi-algorithm, public-key encryption is realized where the communication party has to decrypt only one of the PKESK packages in order to decrypt the message.
```

Since we're talking about signatures here, I guess "verifier" or something like that would work.

An alternative would be to simply state how the verification procedure works, not how an entity (recipient/comm. party) has to perform it. Something like "composite sigs are only considered valid if all component sigs are valid"

"communication party" might be weird in some contexts.

I think the feedback in the Interim was not to avoid the word "recipient" everywhere. I think here it is sufficiently clear what is meant by "recipient" and I think it's the best word to use. The ambiguity comes in when matching multiple keys/certs to a recipient / entity and it becomes a more abstract concept.

For a PKESK packet there is a recipient / recipient key and for a SEIPD message the recipients are each recipient of the list of PKESK packets. I think that's common wording also in the Crypto Refresh.

Yes, it is correct the the term "recipient" is used throughout the crypto-refresh. So we should rather stick to it and probably just avoid conveying the idea of differentiating between keys that belong to a single recipient and to multiple recipients.
Here I think we run into the problem that the abstract concept of a recipient (outside of PKESKs) is not well defined. Might be ok for the non-normative statement, though.

I think that here the word "recipient" would be unterstood in the context of the PKESK packet(s) so it'd be ok to use

Edit: alternative in line 900 looks good, resolving this
Also here I think "recipient" is ok to use
I don't think it's verification only here, if we want to use `verifier` we also need to say `decrypter`?

```suggestion
An implementation SHOULD use `AES-256` in the case of a v1 SEIPD packet, or `AES-256` with any available AEAD mode in the case of a v2 SEIPD packet, if all recipients indicate support for it (explicitly or implicitly).
```
I think it's fine as an explanation of the previous sentence

reviews.author: dkg
reviews.body: I'm with @TJ-91 in that i think "communication party" has gotten too abstract to be useful.  can we pull back a little bit?

comments.body: seems to me that we have a "generating" implementation and a "consuming" or "evaluating" implementation.  "Communication party" is rather too vague.

what is a "PKESK package"?  does this mean "packet"?  i recognize it's not a part of the text edited here, but it could be cleaned up while we're touching this line.

again, i think "communication party" is too generic.  we're talking about the "consuming" or "evaluating" implementation, not the generating implementation.  in this case, we're just talking about decryption, so we could just say "the decrypting party".
This was completely moved and re-worded, avoiding the concept of communication party or recipient
Up to you all, this makes no difference in my opinion

reviews.author: falko-strenzke
reviews.body: Looks good to me. Thanks for the work Aron. I just propose two corrections regarding wording.

comments.body:
```suggestion
In section {{pq-key-preference}} it is explained how to deal with multiple key scenarios.
```

```suggestion
In a signature stripping attack, an adversary removes one or more of the signatures such that only a subset of the signatures remain in the message at the point when it is verified.
```

I would still rather rewrite this. IMO that problem is outside of the scope of the OpenPGP protocol and more an application thing. The protocol layer doesn't necessarily know that two certificates / keys that it processes for encrypting are somehow linked. And even if it does, it can't know the intent of the application/user.
See also #67, I think the critique still applies to this: Do we mean the second or the third scenario, or both, and what is the criterion for an application to determine that two certificates belong to the same recipient in the third scenario?

In any case, I would change the paragraph to start with the more obvious case first:

> For instance, in the case that a certificate has both a PQ/T and an ECC encryption-capable valid subkey, the PQ/T subkey SHOULD be preferred.

And then we can add the "multiple certificate scenario" a bit more vaguely. The best I could come up with is the following:

> Further, if an application can determine (by any means not defined in this document) that encrypting to a PQ/T certificate and a traditional certificate serves the same purpose, it should omit encrypting to the traditional certificate.

Sorry for being a bit picky here but I think sooner or later someone will re-raise this issue.

I'd try to state this more concisely since it's more or less stating the obvious.

```suggestion
Furthermore, the OpenPGP protocol also allows parallel encryption to different keys by using multiple PKESK packets, thus realizing non-composite multi-algorithm public-key encryption.
```
After looking closer again I agree with Johannes, here the assumptions about the identity of the recipient will most likely have to be more vague.

```suggestion
For instance, in case that a certificate has both a PQ/T and an ECC encryption-capable valid subkey, the PQ/T subkey SHOULD be preferred.
Furthermore, if an application can anyhow determine that encrypting to a PQ/T certificate and a traditional certificate is redundant, it should omit encrypting to the traditional certificate.
```
What about this?

I think we're almost there. But "SHOULD be preferred" might not be clear enough, as we also want to express that in this case the traditional key should not be used at all. So I would write for instance " ... valid subkey, the PQ/T subkey SHOULD be used and the traditional key SHOULD NOT be used."

Furthermore, I wouldn't write "and an *ECC* encryption-capable valid subkey" but rather "and a *traditional* encryption-capable valid subkey" in order not to create the false assumption that it only refers to ECC keys (other types of keys might be around for quite some time).

That's the point of "for instance", IMO. I would rather remove the normative part from an example then or remove the "for instance".

Normative way:
```suggestion
In case that a certificate has both a valid PQ/T and a valid traditional subkey, an implementation SHOULD use the PQ/T subkey only.
Furthermore, if an application can anyhow determine that encrypting to a PQ/T certificate and a traditional certificate is redundant, it should omit encrypting to the traditional certificate.
```
Example way:
```suggestion
For instance, an implementation that encrypts messages for a recipient for which both a valid PQ/T and a valid ECC encryption subkey are available, the implementation should use the PQ/T subkey only.
Furthermore, if an application can anyhow determine that encrypting to a PQ/T certificate and a traditional certificate is redundant, it should omit encrypting to the traditional certificate.
```
Somehow hybrid, but not normative:
```suggestion
For instance, an implementation that encrypts messages for a recipient for which both a valid PQ/T and a valid traditional encryption subkey are available, the implementation should use the PQ/T subkey only.
Furthermore, if an application can anyhow determine that encrypting to a PQ/T certificate and a traditional certificate is redundant, it should omit encrypting to the traditional certificate.
```

I would write:

> For instance, an implementation that encrypts a message to a certificate for which both a valid PQ/T and a valid traditional encryption subkey are available, the implementation should encrypt to the PQ/T subkey only.

This is adapted from your "Example way" to avoid the "recipient" terminology, and I also replaced "use" by "encrypt to", as well as "ECC" by "traditional".

I'm happy with your suggestion for the "multiple certificate scenario".

I vote for the normative variant @wussler has posted above.

(An example with ECC is in my point potentially misleaing – even though from a formal point it is correct since it is an example. But our aim here by rendering the guidance as an example is only with respect to the set of keys, I don't see a need to make it concrete with respect to the public-key encryption algorithm.)

I also generally agree to the second sentence about the redundant certificate. That solves the problem of the using the word "recipient" well in my view. But the use of the word "anyhow" doesn't seem right to me. I ran the sentence through deepl and it doesn't translate to German correctly. I think we need to replace "anyhow" with "in some way" or with "somehow". Or maybe even better 

"Furthermore, if an application has any means to determine ..."

Ok, then let's go with the normative variant.

I was a bit unsure about "anyhow" myself but cannot judge it. I vote for your suggestion to write "Furthermore, if an application has any means to determine ...".

```suggestion
In case that a certificate has both a valid PQ/T and a valid traditional subkey, an implementation SHOULD use the PQ/T subkey only.
Furthermore, if an application has any means to determine that encrypting to a PQ/T certificate and a traditional certificate is redundant, it should omit encrypting to the traditional certificate.
```

Sorry for the holdup, but I just noticed that we should phrase it a bit narrower. Otherwise this statement also includes the signature case and contradicts what we write in line 905, 906.

```suggestion
When encrypting to a certificate that has both a valid PQ/T and a valid traditional encryption subkey, an implementation SHOULD use the PQ/T subkey only.
```
still needs to be removed

```suggestion
```
Good that you noticed it's missing! I would move the `ecdhPublicKey` line up such that all inputs are in the correct order
